article:
The 'mantle' is a part of a terrestrial planet or other rocky body large enough
to have differentiation by density. The interior of the Earth, similar to the
other terrestrial planets, is chemically divided into layers. The mantle is a
highly viscous layer between the crust and the outer core. Earth's mantle is a
rocky shell about
thick [http://www.glossary.oilfield.slb.com/Display.cfm?Term=mantle Mantle:
Schlumberger Oilfield Glossary] that constitutes about 84% of Earth's
volume. It is predominantly solid and encloses the iron-
rich hot core, which occupies about 15% of Earth's volume. {{cite web |url=http://pubs.usgs.gov/gip/interior/ |title=The
interior of the earth |last=Robertson |first=Eugene |year=2007 |accessdate=2009-01-
06 |publisher=USGS }}
[http://www.glossary.oilfield.slb.com/Display.cfm?Term=core Core:
Schlumberger Oilfield Glossary] Past episodes of melting and volcanism at
the shallower levels of the mantle have produced a thin crust of crystallized
melt products near the surface, upon which we live. {{cite
web |url=http://www.moorlandschool.co.uk/earth/earths_structure.htm |title=The
structure of the Earth |year=2005 |publisher=Moorland School |accessdate=2007-12-
26 }}  Information about structure and composition of the mantle either
result from geophysical investigation or from direct geoscientific analyses on
Earth mantle derived xenoliths.

Two main zones are distinguished in the upper mantle: the inner asthenosphere
composed of plastic flowing rock about 200 km
thick, [http://www.glossary.oilfield.slb.com/Display.cfm?Term=asthenosphere
Asthenosphere: Schlumberger Oilfield Glossary ]. and the lowermost part of
the lithosphere composed of rigid rock about 50 to 120 km
thick. [http://www.glossary.oilfield.slb.com/Display.cfm?Term=lithosphere
Lithosphere: Schlumberger Oilfield Glossary] A thin crust, the upper part
of the lithosphere, surrounds the mantle and is about 5 to 75 km
thick. [http://www.glossary.oilfield.slb.com/Display.cfm?Term=crust Crust:
Schlumberger Oilfield Glossary]

In some places under the ocean the mantle is actually exposed on the surface
of the Earth. http://www.livescience.com/1317-mission-study-earth-gaping-open-
wound.html There are also a few places on land where mantle rock has
been pushed to the surface by tectonic activity, most notably the Tablelands
region of Gros Morne National Park in the Canadian province of Newfoundland
and Labrador.
